text: Google presenting olddddd documentation versions of Julia packages as the top result. It feels like the internet is gaslighting you sometimes. (<@U69BL50BF> in this case, top result for "julia DiffEq" links to v2.0 of the docs) Second result fortunately is correct, but I can't help but think how many new-to-Julia people are less impressed by the docs from nearly 4 years ago....!

text: this comes up a lot. We've given Google metadata hints too

text: Yeah I know it's not your fault. But certainly hazardous for fresh faces

text: Apparently we would need to add noindex to old pages? Cf. <https://github.com/JuliaDocs/Documenter.jl/issues/1302>

text: we already do that in DiffEq

text: Implementing <https://github.com/JuliaDocs/Documenter.jl/issues/1449>  would reduce the "cost" of this problem by a lot.

text: GitHub and Python docs have the same issue. Seems to be a problem with Google and not one that's easily fixable

text:
Numpy is the biggest victim of this, I almost never land on the latest docs

but if you think about it, almost nobody is using the latest version of numpy either, unlike Julia

text: what about moving old versions of docs to different location with a noindex annotation?

elements.text: what about moving old versions of docs to different location with a noindex annotation?

text: alternatively, can we get google to reindex things and pick up the noindex annotation?

elements.text: alternatively, can we get google to reindex things and pick up the noindex annotation?

text: Would also be great to have a big warning stating that this is the docs for an old version click here for the latest docs.
